accordingly  police department purpose this chapter is established in order to establish the lines of authority and responsibility as between the mayor and the board of aldermen and the elected chief of police and his department    police force positionsrules and regulationsfilling vacancies a police force positions the police force of the city in addition to the chief of police shall consist of those positions as established in the budget ordinance of the city the police force shall include all dispatchers and reference in this chapter to policemen or the like shall include dispatchers b rules and regulations of this code shall apply to the police officers of the city however recognizing the special nature of the police force the chief of police with the approval of the board of aldermen may establish such additional rules and regulations as the chief of police deems necessary for the efficient administration management and control of the police force these additional rules and regulations and any amendments thereto shall be kept on file both in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the chief of police in the event of a conflict shall control unless specifically approved and noted by action of the board of aldermen c filling vacancies when a vacancy arises in the police department the following procedure shall apply 1 the personnel clerk with direction from the chief of police shall solicit applications from qualified candidates for vacancies in the department by advertising in professional journals local newspapers and other generally accepted sources 2 the chief of police assistant chief of police personnel clerk and such other police department personnel as the chief of police deems appropriate and necessary shall screen the applications and candidates and select no less than three to present for employment to the interview board 3 the interview board shall consist of the following the president of the board of aldermen chairman of the public safety committee chief of police assistant chief of police and personnel clerk 4 the interview board shall conduct the final interview with the prospective candidates rate the candidates and make its selection to fill the vacancy 5 in the case of an emergency the chief of police may with the approval of the board of aldermen fill vacancies within the police department without a final interview by the full interview board the authorization provided in this subsection may be revoked and rescinded by the board of aldermen at any time and in such event the hiring procedure set forth in subsections c1 4 of this section shall be followed 6 the process for promotions within the police department shall follow a similar process utilizing a threeperson interview board the board shall consist of the citys personnel clerk the supervisor of the position to be filled and the chief of police andor his designee exceptions to this process shall be approved by the board of aldermen  2005  prior code  222  52014   2216   salaryrestrictions on compensation a the salary of the police officers of the city shall be established in the annual city pay plan or other authorize response to emergency situations as defined in said statute within the confines of the county of perry state of missouri and under the specific provisions of revised statutes of missouri 197 as amended in 1977 c this section shall be effective upon the passage of a similar resolution by the county commissioners of perry county missouri d the chief of police of the city is authorized to authorize the response by any peace officer of the city who has completed the police basic training program as promulgated by revised statutes of the state of missouri to emergency situations within the county of perry e no police officer shall respond to any situation whether emergency or otherwise outside of the confines of the city limits without the permission of the chief of police or his designate    fresh pursuitdefined as used in fresh pursuit means the pursuit of a person who has committed a felony or is reasonably suspected of having committed a felony in the state of missouri or who has committed or attempted to commit in the state of missouri a criminal offense or violation of municipal or county ordinance in the presence of a city police officer or for whom such officer holds a warrant of arrest for a criminal offense it shall also include the pursuit of a person suspected of having committed a supposed felony in the state of missouri though no felony has actually been committed if there is reasonable ground for so believing fresh pursuit shall imply instant pursuit    fresh pursuitauthority to conduct every city police officer certified by the missouri director of the department of public safety as a peace officer as provided by mo rev stat 198 as amended is authorized to arrest and hold in custody any person apprehended as the result of fresh pursuit as defined herein subject to the rules and procedures adopted by the city    initiation of fresh pursuit fresh pursuit may only be initiated from within the city limits and shall be terminated once the pursuing officer is outside of his jurisdiction and has lost contact with the person being pursued    fresh pursuittraffic violations if the offense is a traffic violation the uniform traffic ticket shall be used as if the violator had been apprehended in the city and a summons shall be issued by the arresting officer    fresh pursuitwarrant arrests if an arrest is made in obedience to a warrant the disposition of the prisoner shall be made as in other cases of arrest under a warrant    policies and procedures all incidents of fresh pursuit shall be conducted pursuant to the policies and procedures adopted by the city marshal of the city police department and approved by the board of aldermen  police reserve unit created there is created a police reserve unit the membership of which shall consist of not more than six members or onehalf of the full strength of the regular police department officers whichever is greater each member shall be in good physical condition of good character and not less than twentyone 21 years of age appointments to the police reserve unit shall be made by the chief of police with the approval of the board of aldermen for two years providing that any member may be discharged at any time with or without cause and without a hearing by the chief of police or internal review board or the mayor and the board of aldermen regular police officers shall be eligible for membership in the police reserve unit    oathcommissionpowersdutiesservice the police reserve unit shall function under the immediate direction of the chief of police or his designate oath powers and duties will be the same as required of a regular police officer except during probation periods members of the police reserve unit shall have all the powers and authority and shall be subject to all of the duties of members of the regularly constituted police department and shall be subject to the rules and regulations governing the police department  provided however that the membership in the police reserve unit shall not constitute members in the regularly constituted police department nor shall any member of the police reserve unit be entitled to any right or privilege of compensation pension or any other similar right or privilege of members of the regular police department nor any prerequisite or emolument attaching to membership in the regularly constituted police department all members of the police reserve unit will be required to work a minimum number of hours per year as established by the chief of police    training the chief of police shall determine the program for training members of the police reserve unit in police work reserve officers will work within the command structure of the present police department    compensation a no member of the police reserve shall receive any compensation from the city for his services as a member of the police reserve unit except as may be provided from time to time by the board of aldermen b the police reserve unit may not accept donations for their services    uniforms equipment and vehicles a the members of the police reserve unit shall furnish their own uniforms and other necessary equipment without reimbursement from the city except as otherwise provided by ordinance b the police reserve unit shall own no equipment other than their personal uniforms and equipment approved by the chief of police they shall use the existing equipment of the regular police department as designated    selection the chief of police with the approval of the board of aldermen shall appoint reserve personnel  fire department established there is established a fire department in the city    composition the fire department shall consist of a fire chief deputy fire chief and two assistant fire chiefs and other such officers and members as determined is necessary and approved by the board of aldermen  part 2000 prior code  1216   meetings the fire department shall meet at regular monthly meetings and the december meeting shall be the annual meeting of the department    appointment of chief the fire chief shall be appointed in april of each evennumbered year by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen   7511   oath of chief the fire chief shall before entering upon the discharge of his duties be sworn to faithfully perform the duties of office    term of chief the fire chief shall serve in office for the term of two years and until his successor is appointed and qualified unless sooner removed for cause   7511   removal of chief the fire chief may be removed from office by resolution of the board of aldermen at any time for incompetency inefficiency neglect of duty or when it may appear to the board to be in the best interest of the fire department    appointment of deputy chief assistant chiefs and members the deputy fire chief assistant fire chiefs other officers and members of the fire department shall be appointed by the fire chief  part 2000 prior code  1222   dismissal of deputy chief assistant chiefs other officers or members the deputy fire chief assistant fire chiefs other officers or any or all members of the fire department may be summarily dismissed by the fire chief at any time when in his opinion the same will be to the best interest of the fire department  part 2000 prior code  1223   filling of vacancies upon the dismissal or resignation of the deputy fire chief assistant fire chiefs or any or all members of the fire department the fire chief shall immediately proceed to fill such vacancy or vacancies  part 2000 prior code  1224   compensation of members each member of the fire department shall receive such compensation as determined by the board of aldermen    adoption of constitution bylaws and regulations the fire department shall have the authority to adopt a constitution bylaws and regulations for the government of the same    general authority of chief the fire chief shall be commander of the fire department subject only to the orders of the mayor    members to obey orders of chief the deputy fire chief assistant fire chiefs all other officers and members of the fire department shall strictly obey all lawful orders of the fire chief  part 2000 prior code  1228   deputy chiefassistant chiefsduties the deputy chief and the assistant fire chiefs shall assist the fire chief and in the absence of the fire chief act in his stead  part 2000 prior code  1229   members to respond to alarms whenever there is a fire alarm the firefighters shall under the direction of the fire chief deputy fire chief or assistant fire chief proceed as rapidly as possible to the scene of the fire with the fire apparatus and equipment and there work and manage the same under the direction of the fire chief deputy fire chief or the assistant fire chief until the fire is extinguished  part 2000 prior code  1230   departure from fire by members it is unlawful for any member of the department once on the scene to leave task without the permission of the fire chief deputy fire chief assistant fire chief or other fire officer in command at said location  part 2000 prior code  1231   destruction of structures to arrest progress of fire the fire chief or other officer in command at any fire may order the removal of any building or erection for the purpose of arresting the progress of any fire and with the advice of the mayor and two members of the board of aldermen shall have the power to blow up any building or structure for the purpose of arresting the progress of a fire    summoning aid at fire the fire chief deputy fire chief or assistant fire chief shall have the authority to summon any person present to aid in extinguishing any fire or protecting property thereat and it shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to assist when summoned  part 2000 prior code  1233   arrest authority of chief deputy chief and assistant chiefs the fire chief deputy fire chief or the assistant fire chiefs shall have the power to arrest any person refusing to assist the fire department in extinguishing any fire or protecting property thereat when summoned or any person who steals or attempts to steal any property during the progress of the fire and hold such person in custody until he can be dealt with according to law  part 2000 prior code  1234   mutual aid agreements a the fire department shall not answer any fire calls andor use public safety equipment outside the city limits except as hereinafter provided b the city fire department with the approval of the mayor and the board of aldermen may enter into mutual aid agreements with rural fire protection associations municipalities and counties as authorized by state statute such mutual aid agreements shall be entered into only by official action of the mayor and board of aldermen    equipment and apparatus custody and maintenance the fire chief shall have the custody of the fire engines hose carts trucks hooks ladders and other equipment or apparatus of the fire department and it shall be his duty to look after and carefully preserve such equipment or apparatus    equipment and apparatus repair whenever any of the fire engines hose carts trucks hooks ladders and other equipment or apparatus of the fire department need to be repaired the fire chief shall with the advice and consent of the mayor cause such repairs to be made    use of intoxicating liquor by members a it is unlawful for any member of the fire department to be found in a state of intoxication at any fire or to use any intoxicating liquor in or about any fire station b any member of the fire department convicted of violating any provision of subsection a of this section shall after dismissal be ineligible to be a member of the fire department    annual inspection there shall be a general review of the fire department during the month of november of each year    intentional or negligent acts and false alarmsfees and charges a intent the board of aldermen after making a study of the matter finds that the city fire department occasionally must respond to emergency situations both inside and outside the city limits that are the result of intentional or negligent acts and false alarms there should be a means for the city to receive reimbursement for extraordinary expenditures of funds in providing fire suppression services in such instances b when charges incurred fees and charges as set forth in the fee schedule in this section may be imposed for reimbursement of services rendered by the city fire department in the following cases 1 for responses made to a fire or accident which occurred as a result of a negligent or intentional act the fee shall be imposed against the individual or individuals responsible for the act  and 2 for responses made as a result of a maliciously set false alarm or repeated nonmaliciously set false alarms the fee shall be imposed against the individual or individuals responsible for the false alarm c fee schedule the following fee schedule shall apply 1 minimum initial service chargetwo hundred dollars $20000 per fire truck used 2 special equipment fees and substantial personnel hours costs as determined by the fire chief 3 for equipment destroyed or lost while combatting fire and not replaced by proceeds from insurance replacement costs shall be charged consumable items used shall be refunded at replacement cost ie foam air or oxygen d determination of charges the fire chief shall make the determination as to when the fees set forth in this section shall be assessed and which individual or individuals shall be responsible for payment of the fees    hazardous materials incidents fees and charges in incidents involving hazardous materials including but not limited to leaks spills or releases of such hazardous materials the person having control over the hazardous substance shall be liable for such reasonable cleanup and containment costs incurred by the city such liability includes the cost of materials supplies and contractual services actually used to secure an emergency situation the liability may also include the cost for third party contractual services third party services equipment material of any kind or type necessary or desirable for cleanup and containment cost which are not routinely provided by the department or the city  part 2000 municipal court court established there is established in this city a police court to be known as the perryville municipal court a division of the 32nd judicial circuit court of the state of missouri this court is a continuation of the police court of the city as previously established and is termed herein the municipal court    jurisdiction the jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the city    selection of judgecompensation a the judge of the citys municipal court shall be known as the municipal judge of the 32nd judicial circuit court and shall be elected to the position by the qualified voters of this city for a term as specified in b the municipal judge shall receive the sum of one thousand ninetytwo dollars $109200 per month for the 20182020 term of office in lieu of all other fees  2007  2005  2004  2001  1999  1997 prior code  233  12109   12611   12313   12115   2 112117   judgeterm of office the municipal judge shall hold his office for a period of two years and shall take office biannually from the date for an elected official to take office if for any reason a municipal judge vacates his office his successor shall complete that term of office even if the same is for less than two years    judgevacation of office the municipal judge shall vacate his office under the following circumstances a upon removal from office by the state commission on the retirement removal and discipline of judges as provided in missouri supreme court rule 12  b upon attaining his seventyfifth birthday  or c should he fail within six months of his election to satisfactorily complete course of instruction for municipal judge as prescribed by the state supreme court    judgequalifications for office the municipal judge shall possess the following qualifications before he shall take office a he shall be licensed to practice law within the state of missouri b he must reside within perry county missouri c he must be a resident of the state of missouri d he must be between the ages of twentyone 21 and seventyfive 75 years e he may not hold any other office within the city government f the municipal judge shall be considered holding a parttime position and as such may accept within the requirements of the judicial conduct missouri supreme court rule 2 other employment g he shall be a qualified voter under the laws and the constitution of this state and ordinances of the city h no person shall be judge who shall at the time of his election be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes or forfeiture or defalcation in office i no person shall be judge who has been found guilty of or pled guilty to a felony or misdemeanor under the federal laws of the united states or to a felony under the laws of this state or an offense committed in another state that would be considered a felony in this state j no person shall be judge who has not filed a candidates affidavit of tax payments and bonding requirements with the missouri department of revenue form 5120 as required by rsmo  2001 prior code  236  12115   51617   superintending authority the municipal court of the city shall be subject to the rules of the circuit court of which it is a part and to the rules of the state supreme court the municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge of the circuit court and the judge and court personnel of the court shall obey his directives    report to board of aldermen the municipal judge shall cause to be prepared within the first ten days of every month a report indicating the following a list of all cases heard and tried before the court during the preceding month giving in each case the name of the defendant the fine imposed if any the amount of cost the names of the defendants committed and the cases where there was an application for trial de novo respectively the same shall be prepared under oath by the municipal court clerk or the municipal judge this report will be filed with the city clerk who shall thereafter forward the same to the board of aldermen of the city for examination of its first session thereafter the municipal court shall within the ten days after the first of the month pay to the municipal treasurer the full amount of all fines collected during the preceding months if they have not previously been paid    docket and court records the municipal judge shall be a conservator of the peace he shall keep a docket in which he shall enter every case commenced before him and the proceedings therein and he shall keep such other records as may be required such docket and records shall be records of the circuit court of perry county the municipal judge shall deliver the docket and records of the municipal court and all books and papers pertaining to his office to his successor in office or to the preceding judge of the circuit    municipal judgepowers and duties generally the municipal judge is authorized to a establish a traffic violations bureau as provided for in the missouri rules of practice and procedure in municipal and traffic courts and the revised statutes of missouri  b commute the term of any sentence stay execution of any fine or sentence suspend any fine or sentence and make such other orders as the municipal judge deems necessary relative to any matter that may be pending in the municipal court  c make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to implement and carry out the provisions of this chapter and to make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to hear and decide matters pending before the municipal court and to implement and carry out the provisions of the missouri rules of practice and procedure in municipal and traffic courts any and all rules made or adopted hereunder may be annulled or amended by an ordinance limited to such purpose  provided that such ordinance does not violate or conflict with the provisions of the missouri rules of practice and procedure in municipal and traffic courts or state statutes  d the municipal judge shall have power to enforce due obedience to all orders rules and judgments made by him or may fine or imprison for contempt offered to him while holding court and as to process issued by him in the same manner and to the same extent as circuit judges 1 it is declared to be an act of contempt of the municipal court for any person or group of persons to while the court is in session in a regular or special session do or accomplish or encourage or aid or abet in the accomplishments of any of the following a the use of loud or unusual language or discussion in the courtroom after the person or persons have been warned to cease and refrain from committing acts that they were doing  b unruly unsavory unseemly or uncooperative conduct behavior and mannerisms in the courtroom in the presence of the court or public officials of the city designated to intimidate harass heckle or otherwise obstruct delay hinder or disrupt court proceedings 2 the punishment for acts committed within the presence of the municipal judge of the city or other public official of the city shall be punished summarily as the judge may deem expedient in order to punish and otherwise correct bad behavior and set examples for persons who might otherwise be inclined to carry on similar behavior in the future by assessing a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars $10000 or by a jail sentence not to exceed ninety 90 days 3 after due notice and hearing thereon the same punishment shall likewise be had for acts committed without the presence of the municipal judge including but not limited to failure to obey court orders process judgments summonses or warrants  e the municipal judge shall have such other powers duties and privileges as are or may be prescribed by the laws of this state this code or other ordinances of this city  part 2000  prior code  2310   violations bureau there is established a violations bureau and the city shall provide all expenses incident to the operation of the same the city clerk or her designate is designated as the violations clerk for the bureau if established the city clerk or her designate shall accept the appearance waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fine and costs in violations bureau cases or as directed by the municipal judge  generally act as violation clerk of the violations bureau see rule 3749 vamr  part 2000 prior code  2311   issuance and execution of warrants all warrants issued by a municipal judge shall be directed to the city marshal chief of police or any other police officer of the municipality or to the sheriff of the county the warrant shall be executed by the marshall chief of police police officer or sheriff any place within the limits of the county and not elsewhere unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases and when so endorsed shall be served in other counties as provided for in warrants in criminal cases    arrests without warrants the city marshal chief of police or other police officer of the city may without a warrant make arrest of any person who commits an offense in his presence    jury trials any person charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance of this city shall be entitled to a trial by jury as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a municipal ordinance demands trial by jury the municipal court shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment as provided by missouri law  1998 prior code  2314   duties of citys prosecuting attorney it shall be the duty of an attorney designated by the municipality to prosecute the violations of the citys ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge hearing violations of the citys ordinances the salary or fees of the attorney and his necessary expenses incurred in such prosecutions shall be paid by the city the compensation of such attorney shall not be contingent upon the result in any case    prosecutions based on information onlyproceedings all prosecutions for the violation of municipal ordinances shall be instituted by information and may be based upon a complaint proceedings shall be in accordance with the supreme court rules governing practice and procedure in proceedings before municipal judges    summoning of witnesses it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at the trial and to enforce their attendance by attachment if necessary the fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associate circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case when a trial shall be continued by a municipal judge it shall not be necessary to summon any witnesses who may be present at the continuance  but the municipal judge shall orally notify such witnesses as either party may require to attend before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case and enter the names of such witnesses on his docket which oral notice shall be valid as a summons    transfer of complaint to associate circuit judge if in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge it shall appear to the judge that the accused ought to be put upon trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and not cognizable before him as municipal judge he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county    jailing of defendants if in the opinion of the municipal judge the city has no suitable and safe place of confinement the municipal judge may commit the defendant to the county jail and it shall be the duty of the sheriff if space for the prisoner is available in the county jail upon receipt of a warrant of commitment from the judge to receive and safely keep such prisoner until discharged by due process of law the municipality shall pay the board of such prisoner at the same rate as may now or hereafter be allowed to such sheriff for the keeping of such prisoner in his custody the same shall be taxed as cost    parole and probation any judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances may when in his judgment it may seem advisable grant a parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after a trial before such judge the court is authorized to use circuit approved private probation services to supervise requirements of probation  part 2000 prior code  2320   right of appeal the defendant shall have a right to a trial de novo even from a plea of a guilty before a circuit judge or an associate circuit judge such application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten days after the judgment and shall be in the form as provided by supreme court rules    appeal from jury verdicts in all cases in which a jury trial has been demanded a record of the proceedings shall be made and appeals may be had upon that record to the appropriate appellate court    breach of recognizance in the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a municipal ordinance violation case the same shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the principal and surety or either of them in the name of the municipality as plaintiff such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge and in the event of cases caused to be prosecuted by a municipal judge such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge all moneys recovered in such actions shall be paid over to the municipal treasury to the general revenue fund of the municipality    interest or prejudice of judgedisqualification from hearing particular case a municipal judge shall be disqualified to hear any case in which he is in anywise interested or if before the trial is commenced the defendant or the prosecutor files an affidavit that the defendant or the municipality as the case may be cannot have a fair and impartial trial by reason of the interest or prejudice of the judge neither the defendant nor the municipality shall be entitled to file more than one affidavit or disqualification in the same case    temporary municipal judge if a municipal judge be absent sick or disqualified from acting the mayor may designate some competent eligible person to act as municipal judge until such absence or disqualification shall cease  provided however that should a vacancy occur in the office of an elected municipal judge more than six months before a general municipal election then a special election shall be held to fill such vacancy  and in case of vacancy in the office of an elected municipal judge within less than six months of a general municipal election the office may be filled by a competent eligible person designated by the mayor the board of aldermen shall provide by ordinance for the compensation of any person designated to act as municipal judge under the provisions of this section    clerk of municipal court the city clerk is designated as the clerk of the municipal court the city clerk may appoint an assistant city clerk to perform the hereinafter set forth duties provided the city clerk shall be responsible for the performance thereof the duties of the clerk shall be as follows a to collect such fines for violations of such offenses as may be described and the court costs thereof  b to take oaths and affirmations  c to accept signed complaints and allow the same to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before him  d sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum  e perform all other duties as provided for by ordinance by rules of practice and procedure adopted by the municipal judge and by the missouri rules and practice and procedure in municipal and traffic courts and by statute  f maintain properly certified by the city clerk a complete copy of the ordinances of the city of the municipality which shall constitute prima facie evidence of such ordinances before the court further to maintain a similar certified copy on file with the clerk servicing the circuit court of this county    bond any person appointed as and zoning commission established there is established by the city a planning commission and a zoning commission    composition a planning commission the planning commission shall consist of ten members including the mayor a member of the board of aldermen selected by the board annually at its first organizational meeting the city engineer or similar city official and seven citizens appointed by the mayor and approved by the board b zoning commission the zoning commission shall consist of the planning commission as set forth hereinabove  provided however the zoning commission shall in addition be composed of up to three alternate members to be appointed in the same manner as citizen planning commission members the alternate citizen members of the zoning commission shall serve for a fouryear term except that the terms of the alternates first appointed shall be for varying periods so that succeeding terms will be staggered the alternate members shall serve in the absence or disqualification of any of the regular zoning commission members at any regular or special zoning commission meeting alternates may be removed as provided in c designation the planning commission and the zoning commission shall be collectively known as the planning and zoning commission    1 1819   employees not to serve on planning commission or zoning commission no person who is a nonelected fulltime or parttime employee of the city shall be appointed to or serve on the planning commission or the zoning commission  1 7318   term of citizen members the term of each citizen member of the planning commission shall be for four years except that the terms of the citizen members first appointed shall be for varying periods so that the succeeding terms will be staggered    compensation of citizen members all citizen members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation    election of chairman and secretary the planning commission shall elect a chairman and secretary from among the citizen members thereof    term of chairman and secretary the term of the chairman and secretary of the planning commission shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection    vacancies in citizen membership any vacancy in a citizen membership of the planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen    removal of citizen members the board of aldermen may remove any citizen member of the planning commission for cause stated in writing after a public hearing thereon    general authority the planning commission shall have the authority necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote municipal planning    functions generally the planning commission shall perform all of the functions of a planning commission and a zoning commission as provided for in of the revised statutes of the state of missouri    meetings the planning commission shall hold regular and special meetings as it provides by rule a quorum of the planning commission shall consist of four members    2 1819   rules and records the planning commission shall have the authority to adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep records of its proceedings which records shall be available for public inspection    appointment of staff contracting for services the planning commission shall subject to the limitations prescribed in this chapter appoint the employees and staff necessary for its work and may contract with city planners and other professional persons for the services that it requires    expenditures the expenditures of the planning commission exclusive of grants and gifts shall be within the amount appropriated for such purpose by the board of aldermen    furnishing of information by public officials all public officials shall upon request of the planning commission furnish it within a reasonable time all available information it requires for its work    right of entry the members and employees of the planning commission in the performance of the functions of the planning commission may enter upon any land to make examinations and surveys    commission to make and adopt city plan the planning commission shall make and adopt a city plan for the physical development of the city which plan with the accompanying maps plats charts and descriptive and explanatory matter shall show the planning commissions recommendations for the physical development and uses of land and may include among other things a the general location character and extent of streets and other public ways grounds places and spaces  b the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals whether publicly or privately owned  c the acceptance widening removal extension relocation narrowing vacation abandonment or change of use of any of the foregoing  d the general character extent and layout of the replanning of blighted districts and slum areas    preparation of city plan purpose in the preparation of a city plan the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of the existing conditions and probable future growth of the city such plan shall be made with the purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated development of the city which will in accordance with existing and future needs best promote the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development    preparation of zoning plan the planning commission shall prepare a zoning plan for the regulation of the height area bulk location and use of private nonprofit and public structures and premises and of population density    procedure for adoption of city plan the planning commission may adopt a city plan as a whole by a single resolution or as the work of making the city plan progresses may from time to time adopt a part thereof any such part to correspond generally with one or more of the functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the plan before the adoption amendment or extension of the plan or portion thereof the planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon fifteen 15 days notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in at least one newspaper having general circulation within the city such hearing may be adjourned from time to time the adoption of the plan requires a majority vote of the full membership of the planning commission the resolution shall refer expressly to the maps descriptive matter and other matters intended by the planning commission to form the whole or part of the plan and the action taken shall be recorded on the adopted city plan or part thereof by the identifying signature of the secretary of the planning commission and filed in the office of the planning commission identified properly by file number a copy of the plan or part thereof shall be certified to the board of aldermen and the city clerk and a copy thereof shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds and shall be available at the city clerks office for public inspection during normal office hours  1998 prior code  2274   approval of improvements by commissionoverruling disapproval whenever the planning commission adopts the plan of the city or any part thereof no street or other public facilities nor public utility whether publicly or privately owned the location extent and character thereof having been included in the recommendations and proposals of the plan or portions thereof shall be constructed or authorized in the city until the location extent and character thereof has been submitted to and approved by the planning commission in case of disapproval the planning commission shall communicate its reasons to the board of aldermen and the board by vote of not less than twothirds of its entire membership may overrule the disapproval and upon the overruling the board of aldermen or the appropriate board or officer may proceed except that if the public facility or utility is one the authorization or financing of which does not fall within the province of the board of aldermen then the submission to the planning commission shall be by the board having jurisdiction and the planning commissions disapproval may be overruled by that board by a vote of not less than twothirds of its entire membership the acceptance widening removal extension relocation narrowing vacation abandonment change of use acquisition of land for sale or lease of any street or other public facility is subject to similar submission and approval and the failure to approve may be similarly overruled the failure of the planning commission to act within sixty 60 days after the date of official submission to it shall be deemed approval    prerequisites to making public improvements upon adoption of a major street plan and subdivision regulations the city shall not accept lay out open improve grade pave or light any adoption of a city plan  or unless the street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the board of aldermen or the planning commission or on a construction or for the acceptance is first submitted to the planning commission for its approval and approved by the planning commission or if disapproved by the planning commission is passed by the affirmative vote of not less than twothirds of the entire membership of the board    prerequisites for issuance of building permit or erection of building after the adoption of a major street plan no organization createdpurpose there is created a local municipal civil defense organization to minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack    composition of organization the local municipal civil defense organization shall consist of a director and other additional members to be selected by the coordinator in the state survival plan and program    appointment of coordinator term the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve until removed by the mayor    general authority of coordinator a the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall have direct responsibility for the organization administration and operation of such organization subject to the direction and control of the mayor b the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall have the authority to appoint without compensation or remove any member of such organizationeol     general authority of organization the local municipal civil defense organization shall be responsible for the performance of civil defense functions within the territorial limits of the city and may conduct such functions outside of the limits as may be required pursuant to state law    oath every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the local municipal civil defense organization shall before entering upon his duties subscribe to the following oath which shall be filed with the coordinator i___________ do solemnly swear or affirm that i will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the constitution of the united states and the constitution of the state of missouri and the territory institutions and facilities thereof both public and private against all enemies foreign and domestic  that i take this obligation freely without any mental reservations or purpose of evasion  and that i will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which i am about to enter and i do further swear or affirm that i do not advocate nor am i nor have i been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the united states or this state by force or violence  and that during such time as i am affiliated with the local municipal civil defense organization i will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the united states or of this state by force or violence    mobile support teams a the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall form mobile support teams as authorized by the revised statutes of missouri 196 and the state survival plan and program and shall designate the leaders thereof b any member of a mobile support team who is a city employee or officer shall receive the compensation and have the powers duties rights and immunities incident to such employment or office while serving on call to duty by the governor or adjutant general of this stateeol     mutual aid agreements a the mayor with the approval of the governor of this state may enter into mutual aid arrangements or agreements b the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization may assist in the negotiation for reciprocal mutual aid agreements between said organization and other public and private agencies and between the governor of this state and the adjoining states or political subdivisions thereof and shall carry out arrangements or agreements relating to the local unit    cooperation between state and city in emergency in carrying out the emergency powers under the provisions of of the revised statutes of missouri 196 the governor of this state and the mayor or board of aldermen are directed to utilize the services equipment supplies and facilities of existing departments offices and agencies of the state and political subdivisions thereof to the maximum extent practicable and the officers and personnel of all such departments offices and agencies are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the governor and to the disaster shall be merged and become a part of the county library district  personnel rules and regulations basic objectives   basic objectives the purpose of these policies is to provide a uniform set of rules governing cityemployee relations with all the benefits such a program insures the fundamental objectives of good personnel administration sought to be achieved by these policies include a to promote and increase efficiency and economy in the service of the city  b to provide fair and equal employment opportunities to all qualified applicants to enter and advance in city employment on the basis of demonstrated merit and fitness as ascertained practical methods of selection and promotion without regard to gender race color creed handicap or national origin  c to develop a program of recruitment advancement and tenure which will make the service of the city attractive as a career and encourage each employee to render their best services to the city  d to establish and maintain a uniform plan of evaluation and pay based upon the relative duties and responsibilities of position in the service of the city  e to promote high morale among city employees by providing good working relationships uniform personnel policies opportunity for advancement and consideration for employee welfare  part 2007   applicability these policies shall apply to all employees in the service of the city these policies shall not apply to elected officials in that elected officials are governed by this code individual departments may establish internal rules and regulations not governed by this manual with the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen  part 2007  12313   affirmative action policy it is the citys policy to take affirmative action to insure that applicants are employed and that employees are treated during employment without regard to their race color religion gender handicap veteran status or national origin such action shall include but not be limited to the following employment upgrading demotion or transfer  recruitment and advertising  layoff or termination  rates of pay or other forms of compensation  selection for training including apprenticeships  and participation in recreational and educational activities  part 2007   americans with disabilities it is the citys policy to avoid discrimination against a qualified individual with a disability because of the disability of the individual in regard to job application procedure the hiring advancement or discharge of employees employee compensation job training and other terms conditions and privileges of employment  part 2007   harassment policy and procedure the city will not tolerate the harassment of any of its employees and will take immediate positive steps to stop it when it occurs any employee who feels he or she is being subjected to harassment shall immediately contact their immediate supervisor or the next level supervisor if their immediate supervisor is not appropriate complaints may be made orally or in writing the city will immediately conduct an investigation into the allegations of harassment and take corrective action if warranted  part 2007   personnel records personnel history records of each employee are available for inspection by the employee and his supervisory officials  part 2007   reference policy on current or former employees in order to promote fair and equal consideration protect privacy and prevent legal liabilities the city hereby establishes the following personnel policy on reference requests it is the policy and practice of the city to provide all prospective employers with references or recommendations per authorized requests all requests must be directed to the personnel clerk at no time is any supervisor superintendent or department head referred to as supervisor authorized to give references or recommendations without the consent of the personnel clerk or city administrator unauthorized references or recommendations may result in disciplinary action supervisors can provide a personal reference for employees not under their supervision personal references cannot be written on city letterhead or email supervisors assume all legal liabilities when a personal or unauthorized reference or recommendation is given the city will release employment information pertaining to name of employee dates of employment positions held and rate of pay all references and recommendations will contain the information listed above all other information related to performance rehire status or other specific employment information of current or past employees will require a written request from the prospective employer and signed by the current or former employee a copy of any written response or completed form will be placed in the referenced employees personnel file  92012   personnel policy publication within ten days from the date of adoption of these policies they shall be furnished to each employee who shall acknowledge in writing the receipt of such copy the policies shall be reviewed periodically by the city administrator and may be changed by the board of aldermen but no such change will divest any employee of rights accrued under these policies at the time of such change a copy of each change in these policies will be furnished to each employee  part 2007 definitions   definitions as used in these rules unless the context clearly requires otherwise call back means an unscheduled or emergency return to work outside of normal hours or on a holiday or day off at the request of the supervisor it does not mean overtime or holiday work scheduled in advance classification means the assignment of an individual position to an appropriate grade on the basis of kind difficulty and responsibility of the work actually performed in the position compensatory time comp time means that amount of authorized time worked by an employee during the employees pay period which exceeds the total time such employee was regularly scheduled to be on duty vacation sick time or injury leave for which time off from work shall be allowed as regular pay crew leader is a person who is directly in charge of a group of nonsupervisory employees day means any regularly scheduled or specially scheduled work period as designated by the board of aldermen city administrator or department head demotion means an assignment of an employee from a position in one pay grade to a position in another pay grade having a lower maximum salary rate department means a major functional unit of the city government department head means a person appointed by the city administrator and responsible to him for the administration of a department discrimination means any unfair treatment based on race color religion national origin ancestry gender age or handicapping condition as it relates to employment division means a major functional unit of a department division head means a person responsible for administration of the work of a division employee includes all regular parttime and probationary employee and means any person working in the service of the city in an official paid capacity exclusive of temporary employees exempt employee means any employee determined by city policy to be exempted from the requirements of overtime pay as established by the laws of the united states and the rules and regulations of the united states department of labor foreman see supervisor grade is a level on the pay scale to which classified positions are assigned based on the duties responsibilities and qualifications required by the job itself handicap means a physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more of the persons major life activities or a condition perceived as such which with or without reasonable accommodation does not interfere with performing the job utilizing the place of accommodation or occupying the dwelling in question harassment means any conduct which may create a hostile environment including but not limited to making slurs using offensive terms telling jokes or creating any work consequences based on anothers race color religion ancestry national origin age gender veteran status disability or handicap immediate family means mother father sister brother spouse son daughter fatherinlaw motherinlaw brotherinlaw sisterinlaw grandmother grandfather soninlaw daughterinlaw grandchild stepchild or any relative living in the same household job see position layoff means a separation from employment because of the citys shortage of funds or materials abolishment of positions or other reasons beyond the control of an employee and not reflecting a discredit to him military leave means the leave of absence granted to employees entering the armed forces of the united states during a national emergency or in response to draft or call to duty from the ready reserve of the armed services month means one calendar month nonexempt employee means any employee determined by city policy not to be exempted from the requirements of overtime pay as established by the laws of the united states and the rules and regulations of the united states department of labor on call means being available for work at a designated place for a designated period of time overtime means any hours over forty 40 in a sundaysaturday work week that are worked by a nonexempt employee any overtime hours worked must be authorized by a supervisor in advance except for emergency situations supervisors may arrange for the employee to take time off in the same work week in lieu of overtime pay whenever possible time employee means any employee that works under one thousand five hundred 1500 hours per year for the city performance increase means an advancement to a higher classification physicians means medical or osteopathic doctors licensed by the missouri state board of medical examiners position or job means a group of current duties and responsibilities legally assigned or delegated by an appointing authority requiring the fulltime or temporary employment of one person probationary employee means a working test period of one hundred eighty 180 days during which an employee is required to demonstrate the employees fitness for a position by actual performance of the duties of the position promotion means an assignment of an employee from a position in one grade to a position in another grade having a higher maximum salary rate qualified individual with a disability means an individual with a disability who with or without reasonable accommodation can perform the essential functions of the employment position that such individual holds or desires range is a series of steps on the pay scale assigned to each grade reasonable accommodation means and includes making existing facilities used by employees readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities and job restructuring modifying work schedules acquisition or modification of equipment andor training materials and the like reevaluation means a change in classification of an individual position on the basis of a review of the kind difficulty or responsibility of work performed in such position regular employee means an employee intended by the city to work forty 40 hours per week or two thousand eighty 2080 hours per year residency shall for the purpose of this provision be defined as the actual living quarters of the employee and hisher family if any and this requirement shall not be met by maintenance of an address room or rooms by the employee solely for the purpose of giving the appearance of compliance herewith when the actual facts demonstrate employees intent to remain outside the geographical area permitted in this chapter residency shall mean residence within the corporate limits of the city service credit means the credit allowed for an employees length of service when completing certain benefits such as vacation sick time and retirement sexual harassment means unwelcome conduct in the form of pinching grabbing patting propositioning  making either explicit or implied job threats or promises in return for submission to sexual favors  making inappropriate sexoriented comments on appearance including dress or physical features  telling embarrassing sexoriented stories  displaying sexually explicit or pornographic material no matter how it is displayed  or sexual assaults on the job by supervisors fellow employees or nonemployees sexual harassment includes conduct directed by men toward women by men toward men by women toward men and by women toward women superintendent means the member of management who has responsibility for a functional area including supervising the nonexempt employees assigned to that area supervisor means any person designated and responsible for directing the work of others temporary employee is an employee who has been appointed for a period of time normally not to exceed twelve 12 months transfer means any change of an employee from one position to another position having the same salary range see also promotion and demotion undue hardship is an action requiring significant difficulty or expense when considered in light of 1 the nature and cost of the accommodation  2 the overall financial resource of the city  3 the number of persons employed  4 the effect such an expense would have on the city  or 5 other impact workday or working day means any one shift during which a department is open for business or on which an employee is scheduled to work workweek means no more than forty 40 hours regularly to be worked by an employee during any seven consecutive days unless overtime hours are paid at a premium rate or unless compensatory time is allowed all pursuant to the fair labor standards act or as may be varied for police or fire work pursuant to the fair labor standards act which act is cited as 29 usc  part part 2007   contents of the plan the wage and salary administration plan consists of city wage schedules and a grouping of city positions according to type of work difficulty and responsibility the wage schedule consists of a listing of all job titles and their corresponding rates of pay each job shall be distinguished by written specification including job title a list of duties and responsibilities and a statement of the minimum qualifications necessary for satisfactory performance of the duties of the job  part 2007   maintaining the plan the city administrator shall be responsible for continuous maintenance and administration of the plan in consultation with the department concerned he shall classify each new position in the service of the city into a temporary grade or range until specifications can be prepared and approved he shall revise existing specifications as the need arises department heads will notify the city administrator when they desire to establish a new position or to modify an existing one and the city administrator will keep them informed of all classification changes a when a new position is created or an existing position is changed by adding modifying or taking away assignments that position will be evaluated and properly classified b the city administrator will make periodic reviews of all positions in a single department or of all the positions in a particular range as a result of his study he may submit to a job evaluation committee a recommendation to reevaluate individual positions  or he himself may recommend a reevaluation subject to the approval of the board of alderman c an employee may submit to his department head a written request for reevaluation of his position this request shall set forth reasons justifying reevaluation the department head will study each request and forward it with his recommendations to the city administrator the city administrator will study the position in question revise the job specifications if necessary and submit his findings and recommendations in writing to the department head written notice of the final determination will be furnished to the employee within sixty 60 days of the request for reevaluation d an employee who occupies a position which is reevaluated shall continue in that position in the new range only if he or she possesses the minimum requirements and is appointed in accordance with the rules governing transfer promotion or demotion 1 when a position is reevaluated to a lower range the employee may continue in his position in the new range see  or he or she may apply for transfer to a position in the original range if the employee continues in hisher position in the new range the employee shall receive no raise in pay until such time as the new range reaches hisher pay amount 2 when a position is reevaluated to a higher range the incumbent employee if he or she has the minimum qualification may continue in the position e reasonable accommodations for the known physical or mental limitations or disability of an employee or applicant who is otherwise qualified to perform the essential functions of the position shall be made by the city unless the requisite accommodations would impose an undue hardship on the city  part 2007   use of job title all jobs are designated by job titles on all official records payrolls and communications no job will carry an official title which has not been approved by the board of aldermen  part 2007   certification license or education if the city administrator determines that a certification license or education is necessary or essential to provide better service to the city then the city administrator may with approval of the board of aldermen establish a compensation schedule providing for compensation to employees who obtain the certification license or education set forth in the schedule  part 2007   continuous study of salary rates prior to the preparation of each annual budget the city administrator shall prepare an analysis of prevailing rates of pay for similar public and private employment in the area and at large taking into consideration cost of living factors budget effects of various alternative pay plans and other factors which may be pertinent in recommending changes in the plan on the basis of this information he shall recommend to the board of aldermen changes in pay policy or in individual pay rates necessary to keep the pay plan current uniform and equitable recommended changes in pay policy shall become effective when approved by the board of aldermen  part 2007   pay increases a the pay plan is designed to provide for pay increases to employees to compensate the employees increased value to the city of service with consideration given for the employees performance and efficiency b eligibility for step increases within the classification grade of a position in the pay plan shall be based on the length of service of the employee  however any employee who received an overall performance evaluation below successful shall not be eligible for a step increase in such cases the employee the employees supervisor and the employees department head shall set out a program designed to help the employee attain the successful level in the employees evaluation the employee shall reach the successful level in the employees evaluation within six months or be subject to dismissal if the employee reaches the successful level anytime within the six month period the employees step increase shall be restored c each january all supervisors shall complete an informal supplementary assessment of all employees under their supervision to determine if any employee is in jeopardy of falling below an overall evaluation score of successful in such cases the employee shall receive a written employee evaluation and for those scoring below successful any cost of living adjustment cola shall be withheld beginning in april of that year at that same time the employee the employees supervisor and the employees department head shall set out a program designed to help the employee attain the successful level in the employees evaluation the employee shall reach the successful level in the employees evaluation within six months or be subject to dismissal if the employee reaches the successful level anytime within the six month probation period the employees cola shall be restored d performance increases and promotions shall take effect at the beginning of a pay period and shall be approved by the city administrator before becoming effective  part 2007  2315   total remuneration no employee shall be paid at a rate more than the maximum for his range unless he or she was 2007  10113   change in position a when an employees position is reevaluated or he or she is appointed to a new position in another classification and his current rate of pay is 1 less than the minimum rate of the new position his rate of pay shall be increased to the new minimum rate  2 more than the maximum rate for the new position his rate of pay shall be maintained at the current rate b temporary employee pay rate rate of pay shall be established at the discretion of the department head with the approval of the city administrator  part 2007   overtime a all nonexempt employees who work overtime will be paid for all additional time worked to the nearest quarter hour all overtime will be at the rate of time and onehalf of the regular hourly rate except that overtime on sundays and holidays will be at the rate of double time of the regular hourly rate it is generally the policy of the city that employees work a forty 40 hour work week  therefore compensatory time should be scheduled in the same week in which the overtime is worked if overtime is necessary the department head will determine if compensatory time will be used or overtime will be paid b all nonexempt employees working within the police department will receive compensatory time in lieu of overtime pay as directed by the chief of police or will be paid at the overtime rate set forth in subsection a of this section except as specifically modified in this subsection all at the discretion of the chief of police with the approval of the city administrator all compensatory time will be computed at one and onehalf times the overtime worked example an employee works one hour overtime he or she receives compensatory time of one and onehalf hours nonexempt employees working within the police department shall not be entitled to double time for sundays and holidays if those days are regularly scheduled duty however nonexempt employees working within the police department who are called out on sundays and holidays that are not their regularly scheduled duty will receive compensatory time computed at double the time of overtime worked c nonexempt employees called back shall be paid the applicable overtime rate for the time worked with a minimum of two hours pay a day off shall be considered to begin and end at the same time as a regular workday and work continuing into a day off from a previous call back shall not be entitled to the twohour premium d any employee who works overtime that has not been certified by a department head as necessary and approved by the city administrator may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including discharge e nonexempt employees shall work overtime when necessary and overtime on any job shall be allocated as evenly as possible among all nonexempt employees qualified to do the work payment shall be as provided in this section departments shall keep complete records of overtime and will furnish periodic reports to the city administrator  part 2007  2216   method of payment pay periods and dates of payment shall be set by the board of aldermen all nonexempt employees are paid for the actual number of hours worked during each pay period when absent on authorized sick time or on vacation each employee shall be paid at this regular rate according to vacation and sick time pay policies  part 2007   terminal pay all employees who leave the service of the city for any reason shall receive all pay which may be due them with the following qualification regular employees who have completed at least six months service shall be paid for all unused vacation and personal time accumulated employees who leave before completing their six months service shall not be entitled to any vacation or personal time pay travel work daystravel time attendance at professional conferences seminars conventions schools or visits to other cities in the interest of the city shall be considered to be part of the normal work day when authorized by the city administrator travel time shall be governed as follows a ordinary travel time between home and work is not considered hours of work  b oncall time is not considered hours worked however when an employee oncall gets a call they are on the clock from the time they get the call travel to where they are needed perform the required services and travel back to where they received the call c home to work travel on a special oneday assignment in another city must be counted as hours of work  however the employees normal commute is subtracted on a oneday assignment both the driver and the passenger is on the clock for the duration of the travel time d travel away from home that involves overnight travel is considered work time when it coincides with the employees normal work day on overnight travel both the driver and the passenger is on the clock for any travel time that is over and above the normal work day  part 2007 attendanceaccrual of benefits
